item.title: Comment on Saturday assorted links by M
item.description:
#6: Oddly in the paper the high-meat, high "beverages" (non-alcholic) dietary subgroup (subtype 3) tended to have the highest odds ratio of depression and an anxiety odds ratio that was comparable to the vegetarian group.

As the paper puts it: "Subtype 3, which followed an unhealthy ‘high protein and low fiber dietary pattern’, had lower well-being scores than other subtypes. ... Individuals, such as in subtype 3, who exhibit a higher intake of fatty meat may experience elevated stress levels and a higher risk of mental disorders, as reported in previous studies on the relationship between diet, stress and mental health"

Fit with my feeling that people with a too much meat (pig meat, cow meat, chicken meat) sort of vibe tend to be people who are reliant on stimulation, low self-control, high levels of impatience, and on average maybe have more self-regulation problems.

"Balanced diet", omnivorous, seems to do best (although maybe the healthy diet subgroup improved after controls for genes or something?).

item.title: Comment on Will very large baby bonuses work? by Morris Applebaum IV
item.description:
Reply to H:

Only a small percentage of the workforce is involved in elder care (about 3% in the US). You could maintain the same elder care workforce just by moving some workers from other sectors into elder care; if you don’t want immigration, you could try outsourcing jobs that can be outsourced and having your own workforce specialize in ones that can’t be outsourced like elder care.

Additionally, most Asian elders grew up in pretty severe poverty and have relatively low living expectations compared to Americans so won’t require as much care; they don’t have McMansions that need to be maintained by others and don’t need the pensions needed for that.

This is boiling frog logic. You said, "Even if South Korea’s population falls by two-thirds," IT ALREADY HAS among the only relevant population, youth. In 1981, there were 867,410 babies born. In 2023, about 240,000. Given the TFR now, they'll be under 100,000 in one more generation.

Your elder care plan better involve 70-year-olds taking care of 90-year-olds. :) Either way, I'm afraid to inform you that old women can't give birth. South Korea already pretty much is the Walking Dead. All those South Korean old men wandering the subways for free all day with no grandchildren, no legacy. That is South Korea. And things are getting much, much worse.
